headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the United Technologies Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Conference Call. On the call today are Greg Hayes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Akhil Johri, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Paul Lu
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the United Technologies Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Conference Call. On the call today are Greg Hayes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Akhil Johri, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Paul Lundstrom, Vice President, Investor Relations. This call is being carried live on the Internet and there's a presentation available for download from UTC's website at www.utc.com. 
Please note, except where otherwise noted, the company will speak to results from continuing operations and excluding restructuring costs and significant other items of nonrecurring and/or nonoperational nature often referred to by management as significant other items. The company also reminds listeners that the earnings and cash flow expectations and any other forward-looking statements provided in this call are subject to risks and uncertainties. UTC's SEC filings including its 10-Q and 10-K reports provide details on important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated in the forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions] Please go ahead, Mr. Hayes.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Kaylie, and good morning, everyone. As you saw on today's press release, we reported full year 2015 adjusted EPS of $6.30. That's at the high end of the guidance range that we gave you for last year. Sales were just north of $56 billion a
componenttext:
Okay, thank you, Kaylie, and good morning, everyone. As you saw on today's press release, we reported full year 2015 adjusted EPS of $6.30. That's at the high end of the guidance range that we gave you for last year. Sales were just north of $56 billion and segment operating margins were a solid 16.7% for the year. I'm pleased to say that despite a very tough macro environment, we remain confident in our full year 2016 adjusted EPS guidance of $6.30 to $6.50 a share. That's on sales of $56 billion to $58 billion. 
As I reflect back on 2015, we took a number of decisive actions and I'm encouraged by the progress the team has made on our strategic priorities. First of all, we streamlined the portfolio, we simplified the organization structure and we returned $12 billion to shareowners. And most importantly perhaps, we achieved some key program milestones. 
As you know we announced and closed the sale of Sikorsky for a very good price, $9 billion, and that generated a $3.4 billion after-tax gain in the fourth quarter and enabled us to initiate a $6 billion accelerated share repurchase program in November. As a result of the divestiture, UTC is now more focused on its core businesses as creating and supplying innovative and game-changing technologies for the building and aerospace industries. Going forward, this portfolio will have a better organic growth profile. It will have higher operating margins and will have stronger cash flows.
We've also simplified the organization. We eliminated the Propulsion and Aerospace Systems layer and the building and industrial systems layer. That creates a flatter, more efficient structure with greater visibility and, importantly, greater accountability. And we now have 4 focused business units that are well positioned to deliver long-term sustainable top and bottom line growth. 
On the cost front, we announced $1.5 billion of multiyear restructuring plans. That included $400 million of restructuring we initiated in 2015. That restructuring is focused on enhancing the long-term cost competitiveness of the company. We expect this restructuring plan to generate about $900 million of run rate savings by 2019. 
We also returned over $12 billion to shareowners last year through dividends and share repurchase. That includes the $6 billion ASR we announced in November. After completion of the ASR this year, we continued to expect to return at least another $3 billion through additional share repurchase plus more than $2 billion of dividends for the year. Clearly, the best M&A opportunity we see right now is UTX stock. We'll continue our share repurchase program as long as we feel there's a significant discount between the intrinsic value of UTC and the share price.
Well, this program execution continues to be a top priority, and we achieved several key milestones in 2015. The Pratt-powered Joint Strike Fighter achieved initial operational capability for the Marines back in July. The A320neo aircraft was certified. The C-Series aircraft was certified, both with Pratt's geared turbofan engines and number of UTAS systems. The Mitsubishi regional jet also had its first flight and the Embraer air engine began testing on our flying test bed. These are programs that will drive growth for decades to come not only at Pratt but at our UTC Aerospace Systems business as well.
I'm proud to say that the dream of the GTF is now a reality. The first Pratt & Whitney powered A320neo was delivered last week to Lufthansa and entered into revenue service this past Monday, and we're meeting our commitments on day 1 for fuel burn, emissions and noise for the first time in aerospace history that an engine delivered everything it was supposed to on day 1. That's a remarkable performance by both Pratt and Airbus. And let me be crystal clear, we're extremely confident in the technology of the Geared Turbofan. 
On the commercial side, we continued to achieve key wins. At Otis, we won the Hudson Yards project in New York and the world's largest hotel, the Abraj Kudai in Saudi Arabia. The Climate, Controls & Security, we secured the new [indiscernible] stadium in Georgia and the Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Center in Kuwait, to name just a few. So overall, I'm proud of our accomplishments in 2015. And as we move forward, the priorities are largely the same that we laid out a year ago. That is, first of all, flawless execution, innovation to drive long-term growth, structural cost reduction and most importantly perhaps, disciplined capital allocation. We remain focused on what we can control, which means controlling costs while continuing to invest and deliver differentiated products and services that will bring value to our customers over the long term.
So despite this mixed macroenvironment that we're all facing, UTC is taking the actions necessary to drive long-term sustainable top and bottom line growth and create real long-term shareholder value. 
Let me turn it over to Akhil and Paul to take you through the quarterly and full year results. And I'll be back with a few closing comments and Q&A. Akhil?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. So I'm on Slide 2. Adjusted EPS was $6.30. That's down 2% versus the prior year and up slightly excluding a $0.19 impact from adverse foreign exchange. Full year GAAP earnings per share of $4.53 included restructuring charges of $0.31 and an
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. So I'm on Slide 2. Adjusted EPS was $6.30. That's down 2% versus the prior year and up slightly excluding a $0.19 impact from adverse foreign exchange. Full year GAAP earnings per share of $4.53 included restructuring charges of $0.31 and an additional $1.46 of net charges from other significant items. As we told you back in December, a lot of moving pieces this quarter. So let me walk you through a few of the larger pieces that make up the $1.46 of other significant items using the table on the right side of the page. This morning's press release tables have a more detailed reconciliation. 
The largest item is a $0.72 charge for the previously disclosed $867 [ph] million settlement of the Canadian royalty obligation at Pratt Canada. There were also $0.41 of charges for tax-related items. Roughly 75% of that is for U.S. taxes on the planned repatriation of $1.4 billion of cash related to foreign earnings. This will happen over the next couple of years. Our aerospace businesses recorded $0.27 of charges for customer contractual matters. $0.21 of that was at Aerospace Systems related to the completion of significant customer negotiations including the enhancement of our contractual position on a key program, the settlement of certain customer contract disputes and a contract termination.
At corporate, we recognize the liability of $0.17 for pending and future asbestos-related claims. This was based on an analysis of our claims history, broader nationwide asbestos claim trend data and, most importantly, recent agreements reached with insurers. On the other side of the ledger, you'll recall, in Q1, we had a gain on a fair value adjustment related to the acquisition of a controlling interest in a CCS joint venture. That was a $0.14 benefit. .
Now net income for the year was reduced by these charges resulting in free cash flow to net income of 126%. In that number, the benefit from net noncash restructuring charges and other significant items was slightly more than 25 points.
Moving to Slide 3. Organic sales were up 1% for both the year and the quarter in what continues to be a slow growth macro environment. Looking at the fourth quarter, our commercial businesses saw 4% growth in the Americas, driven by continuing strong fundamentals in the U.S. Europe was down 2% primarily from continued pressure in the Otis service business, and Asia was down 1% due to China, where sales were down 4%. Growth in commercial aerospace was primarily driven by the aftermarket both at Pratt and UTAS. Military aerospace sales were down 11% mainly due to tough prior year compare on engine deliveries at Pratt. Military aftermarket was down slightly at both Pratt and UTAS. 
I'm pleased to say that Pratt has resolved the supply chain delays experience in Q3 at the New England Logistics Center or NELC. They're back to their pre-NELC delivery cadence and were on schedule with deliveries for large commercial engines and the Joint Strike Fighter as of year-end.
Taking a closer look at our end markets on Slide 4. And just a reminder, we'll talk to Otis and CCS orders on a constant currency basis as we usually do. Overall trends remain broadly consistent with our expectations across the portfolio. In our commercial businesses, we continue to see good momentum in North America, particularly at Otis where North America new equipment orders were up over 50% in the quarter and 30% for the year. This is on top of 40% growth in 2014, so very encouraging trends here. At CCS, U.S. commercial HVAC equipment was down 5% in the quarter, driven mainly by a slowing export market and tough compares in military. For the full year, orders were up 5%. U.S. residential HVAC sales were up 2% in the quarter and up 5% for the full year.
EMEA was somewhat mixed in the quarter. Otis new equipment orders were strong up 20%. At CCS, commercial HVAC equipment orders were also up 4%, while Fire & Security products orders were down 7%. In China, Otis new equipment orders were down 14% in the fourth quarter and finished down 13% for the full year. On the other hand, CCS Fire & Security orders in China were up 8% and commercial HVAC was flat, an improvement compared to trends earlier in the year.
Moving to aerospace. Revenue passenger miles continued to grow at slightly above the long-term trend rate and airline profitability remains strong. At Pratt & Whitney, [indiscernible] commercial aftermarket sales were up 11% in the quarter including a 3 point benefit from sale of legacy engine hardware. At UTC Aerospace Systems, commercial aftermarket sales were up 8% on strong repair and provisioning activities. 
Now before I let Paul take you through the additional details for 2015, let's talk briefly about the first quarter of 2016. Based on our expectation of slowly improving economy as the year progresses and easier compares in the second half, we expect 2016 to be back-end loaded. Additionally, the second half of 2016 will benefit from declining E&D trends and higher cost savings. Also, recall the first quarter of 2015 benefited by about $0.10 from timing of a few exceptional items. First quarter last year was also the highest organic growth quarter of the year for CCS and UTAS. We had a slowing but still growing China for Otis and lower negative engine margins at Pratt. Primarily due to these factors as compared to an adjusted EPS of $1.44 in Q1 2015 and consistent with our plan, we expect adjusted EPS in the range of $1.35 to $1.40 for the first quarter of 2016. This includes about $0.08 to $0.10 benefits from lower share count and another $0.10 in pension tailwind. As Greg said, we remain fully confident in our full year 2016 adjusted EPS guidance of $6.30 to $6.60. 
With that, let me hand it off to Paul to walk you through the business units in detail. Paul?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay thanks, Akhil. So turning to Otis on Slide 5. In the quarter, sales were $3.1 billion, up 1% at constant currency. Otis profit was $561 million and down 13% also at constant currency, reflecting increased pricing pressure principally from China and t
componenttext:
Okay thanks, Akhil. So turning to Otis on Slide 5. In the quarter, sales were $3.1 billion, up 1% at constant currency. Otis profit was $561 million and down 13% also at constant currency, reflecting increased pricing pressure principally from China and the margin impact from softer service sales in Europe and lower new equipment volume in China. Foreign exchange translation was an 8 point headwinds to sales and earnings. Otis also had headwind from foreign-currency-related mark-to-market adjustments in the quarter. New equipment sales increased 1%, led by 26% growth in North America and mid-single digit growth in Asia outside of China. EMEA new equipment sales were up 1%, while China was down 7%. Service sales for Otis were flat overall as mid-single-digit growth in both Asia and the Americas was offset by a 5% decline in EMEA. New equipment orders were up 2% in the quarter. The strong momentum in North America continued with orders up over 50% on continued strength in major projects. In EMEA, new equipment orders were up 20% with strong growth in most major markets excluding Russia. New equipment orders in China were down 14%. That's 8% on a unit basis while new equipment orders in the rest of Asia were up 15% excluding the impact of the Thompson line at Metro project in Singapore that we referenced last year. For the full year, operating profit was down 3% at constant currency on 1% higher organic sales. Foreign exchange translation for the year had a 9-point unfavorable impact on both sales and profit. New equipment orders finished up 4% with solid growth in North America and in EMEA, partially offset by a 10% decline in Asia, driven by the 13% decline we saw in China. Outside of China, Otis global new equipment orders were up 17%.
Moving to Slide 6. Climate, Controls & Security grew sales 3% at constant currency with 3 points of tailwind from net acquisitions and flat sales organically. Profits were up 5% at constant currency with continued benefits from restructuring and other productivity. Overall, foreign exchange translation was a 5-point headwind to both sales and earnings. During the quarter, we saw continued sales growth in HVAC in North America where commercial HVAC was up 9%. EMEA saw growth in HVAC as well, up 4% organically, and Asia was down 7% driven by lower China. Overall, sales growth in HVAC was partially offset by 2% declines in both the Fire & Security product and field businesses globally. The Fire & Security business in China was up 9%. Our global refrigeration business was flat in the quarter with mid-single-digit growth in Transicold offset by mid-single-digit declines in commercial refrigeration. CCS equipment orders were down 5% in the quarter, primarily driven by last year's tough compare Transicold. If you recall last year, Transicold saw orders up more than 50% in the quarter. In the Fire & Security business, we were down mid-single digit globally with pressure from the oil and gas sector. For the full year, operating profit was up 7% at constant currency, driven by a drop-through from the 3% organic sales growth and productivity including lower commodity costs.
Shifting to aerospace on Slide 7. Pratt & Whitney sales of $4 billion were flat organically in the quarter. Commercial aftermarket sales grew 11% in the quarter supported by low teens growth in the commercial engines business, primarily from the V2500 up 26% in the quarter and approximately $60 million from the sale of legacy engine hardware. Military sales were down 15% on lower engine deliveries and large commercial OE sales were also down 15%, primarily on engine mix as Pratt shipped more V2500 engines and fewer PW4000s than in the fourth quarter of 2014. Operating profit was down 1% in the quarter. Headwinds from lower military volume, along with higher negative engine margin and pension headwind, were largely offset by a drop-through from the stronger commercial aftermarket, continued declines in E&D spending and better warranty experience. For the full year, Pratt sales were down 1% organically, driven by lower engine deliveries in all segments and lower military aftermarket sales. Commercial aftermarket growth was 6% for the year. Operating profit was down $150 million in 2015. Headwinds from pension, negative engine margin and lower military aftermarket were partially offset by margin from the commercial aftermarket and lower E&D spending.
Turning to Slide 8. Aerospace Systems sales were up 4% organically in the quarter. Consistent with the last 3 quarters, sales included the benefits of a change in arrangement that added around $80 million of pass-through sales with no margins. Excluding those pass-through sales, the commercial OE business was up 2% in the quarter, with growth in new platforms partially offset by declines in legacy. Commercial aftermarket sales were up 8% organically in the quarter, largely driven by growth in provisioning for the A320neo and the 787. Overall, commercial spares finished the year with a book-to-bill of 1 0. Military OE sales were down high-single digit in the quarter, driven by declines in the C-17 and other programs and the military aftermarket was down as well, about 1%. Aerospace Systems profits were down 10% in the quarter. The year-over-year decline was driven by lower military sales, unfavorable commercial OE sales mix as we began transitioning to newer platforms, higher pension expense and lower contribution from licensing activities. These headwinds are partially offset by higher commercial aftermarket volume and continued cost reduction. Engineering spending was essentially flat in the quarter. For the full year, Aerospace Systems sales grew 3% organically with about 2 points of benefit from the pass-through sales mentioned before. Profits for Aerospace Systems were down 3% for the year driven by adverse OE mix, lower military sales and higher pension expense partially offset by continued benefits from the productivity, lower engineering expense, income from licensing agreements and benefits from both higher commercial aftermarket sales and favorable aftermarket contract adjustments.
So with that, let me turn it back to Greg for the wrap-up.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay thanks, Paul. As I mentioned at the beginning of the call, I am encouraged the team's making. With the actions we've taken, we are much better positioned for the future. There is, of course, some uncertainty surrounding the macroeconomic environment.
componenttext:
Okay thanks, Paul. As I mentioned at the beginning of the call, I am encouraged the team's making. With the actions we've taken, we are much better positioned for the future. There is, of course, some uncertainty surrounding the macroeconomic environment. If you think about the 3 biggest markets for UTX, starting with the U.S., I think it's a relatively solid outlook for U.S. GDP growth despite what we've seen in the equity markets in January. China, as you know, is working through some structural challenges. And in Europe, we're starting to see signs of the recovery continues apace. Against this backdrop, we see continued growth in our North American markets and we expect that Europe will continue to slowly improve based on the order rates and the backlog as we exit the year. China will be down for 2016, but let's keep China in perspective. While it's certainly experiencing some challenges as it grapples with reform and rebalance its economy from an industrial growth story to a consumer consumption economy, its long-term growth prospects remain strong. We still expect to see 100 million people urbanized in the next 5 years or so in China. And by 2025 there forecast to be 221 million cities in China with more than 1 million inhabitants. Just to put that in perspective today, in Europe, there are 35 cities with more than 1 million inhabitants. So urbanization will continue to be a powerful force and it will drive growth in our commercial and aerospace businesses going forward.
On the aerospace side, RPMs are continuing to grow. We saw that last year with more than 7% RPM growth, and the airlines are making money and the backlogs are there. Right now for UTC, it's about program execution and program costs. Again, we continue to be confident in our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance of $6.30 to $6.60 and sales of $56 billion to $58 billion. 
Given the portfolio and the team we have today, I've never been more confident about the future of UTC. Our long-term outlook remains strong. Innovative products and industry-leading franchises, global scale and solid market fundamentals in our core businesses, driven by revenue passenger mile growth and the global expansion and continued urbanization of the middle class, have positioned UTC to deliver strong earnings growth well into the future. And all of this will create long-term shareowner value. 
It's important to remember in today's turbulent environment that UTC designs and manufactures products that people rely on every single day. Our products enable modern life and are installed and service for decades regardless of the economic cycle. Our balance between aerospace and commercial are balanced between new equipment and service and our balance geographically would help us whether these uncertain times. 
Before we wrap it up today, just a word on the transition at Pratt, I'd like to, first of all, take a minute to welcome Bob [indiscernible] back to UTC. You recall, Bob is the new President at Pratt & Whitney following the announcement of Paul Adams' retirement earlier this month. As you know, Bob most recently led Sikorsky, and Bob's leadership was instrumental in the successful sale of that business last year. I'd also like to thank Paul Adams for his many contributions to the company and his tireless work over the last 6 years in bringing all of these engines to the marketplace. We wish Paul nothing but success in the future. 
With that, let's go ahead and open up the call to questions. Kaylie?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell with Crédit Suisse.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question first on the organic sales trends. So should we expect organic sales overall to be down a few points in Q1 and then sort of stable in Q2, and then up kind of low mid-single digit in the back half to get that 1 to 3 guide for the year?
componenttext: Just a question first on the organic sales trends. So should we expect organic sales overall to be down a few points in Q1 and then sort of stable in Q2, and then up kind of low mid-single digit in the back half to get that 1 to 3 guide for the year?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably going to be more in the 0 to 1% range in the first quarter. It's not likely to be negative. I think there were some tough compares, but close to 0 to 1% I would say and then slowly improving as the year progresses.
componenttext: I think it's probably going to be more in the 0 to 1% range in the first quarter. It's not likely to be negative. I think there were some tough compares, but close to 0 to 1% I would say and then slowly improving as the year progresses.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You got to keep in mind, Julian, you see, despite what we saw in China for Otis, new equipment orders continue to be up globally. And I would think that backlog will continue to play out, so Otis should have a very solid year outside of China. And Europe
componenttext: You got to keep in mind, Julian, you see, despite what we saw in China for Otis, new equipment orders continue to be up globally. And I would think that backlog will continue to play out, so Otis should have a very solid year outside of China. And Europe is recovering, so again, it's not all doom and gloom here.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then on Otis, that can be a tough margin performance in Q4. You guided in December I think for another $250 million price mix headwind this year. Just wanted to check how confident you feel in that guidance for now, and maybe explain a little bi
componenttext: Sure. And then on Otis, that can be a tough margin performance in Q4. You guided in December I think for another $250 million price mix headwind this year. Just wanted to check how confident you feel in that guidance for now, and maybe explain a little bit when you think we should start to see some of those market share improvements show up in orders or revenues.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think the pricing pressure is continuing to be there to the point you made. We did see increased pricing pressure in China this quarter and the Europe service business has not seen much improvement in its pricing environment as of now. On the other h
componenttext: So I think the pricing pressure is continuing to be there to the point you made. We did see increased pricing pressure in China this quarter and the Europe service business has not seen much improvement in its pricing environment as of now. On the other hand, there is additional cost improvements that Otis is continuing to push for. A part of a big commodity tailwind that we're seeing will also help improve the Otis tailwind from the cost side. Remember, they have 40,000 service vehicles. So the lower the gap lean [ph] prices are, the better it is from our service cost point of view. So we continue to look at cost to offset the incremental pricing pressure, but net-net, pricing is probably slightly higher than what we were thinking in December. Now with regard to margins for the current quarter, Julian, keep in mind, we took this -- a significant mark-to-market FX hit in the quarter which impacted margin by nearly 100 basis points, which is not normal for Otis. So if you adjust for that, Q4 margins were not back far out of line versus our 2016 guidance.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to talk about GTF. I realize it's quite an accomplishment, Greg, but there's an enormous industrialization challenge and we've clearly gotten some indications from Airbus that it's going to be go slow before you go fast. So could you articulate how y
componenttext: Just to talk about GTF. I realize it's quite an accomplishment, Greg, but there's an enormous industrialization challenge and we've clearly gotten some indications from Airbus that it's going to be go slow before you go fast. So could you articulate how you're going to move forward with the engines so that the customer acceptance is flawless?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, it's a great question. As I mentioned many times over the past year, the single biggest challenge that UTC is the ramp on the GTF and coming down the cost curve on the GTF so that we can actually improve overall performance at Pratt. You're exactl
componenttext: Howard, it's a great question. As I mentioned many times over the past year, the single biggest challenge that UTC is the ramp on the GTF and coming down the cost curve on the GTF so that we can actually improve overall performance at Pratt. You're exactly right. There is going to be a relatively slow ramp in the first half of the year. No change to the full year however. We still expect to deliver about 200 GTF engines. Most of those, of course, will go to Airbus. There will be some going to Bombardier for the C-Series aircraft. But I think we're following the lead of Airbus on this, but we think this is the prudent thing in terms of ramping up production relatively slowly entering the service, and we want to have flawless entry in the service across all of the airline customers and this gives us the opportunity to ensure if that exactly happens. So far, it's been wonderful at Lufthansa this week since we put the engine into service and we expect that trend to continue. The engine's in great shape technically, and we will focus again on supply chain execution throughout the year. I think Bob Leduc will hit the ground running there. He spent a lot of time in his first week on the job focused on this, and this is going to be the game for Pratt this year.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just a follow-up. You wouldn't have made this management change if execution weren't part of the issue. and so how do we think about the P&L impact? And also the ramp in '17 is stunningly high and probably not achievable the way you've laid it out. So
componenttext: But just a follow-up. You wouldn't have made this management change if execution weren't part of the issue. and so how do we think about the P&L impact? And also the ramp in '17 is stunningly high and probably not achievable the way you've laid it out. So how -- I mean we're going to see a restructuring at some form because you're not going to get there I think under the old plan.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, did you get cranky this morning and forget your coffee? Let me just [indiscernible] .
componenttext: Howard, did you get cranky this morning and forget your coffee? Let me just [indiscernible] .

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, but in all seriousness, Greg, I mean you have a remarkable optimism but I want you to play into the downside so that we can -- you see something that's a little bit better, but that hill is huge.
componenttext: No, but in all seriousness, Greg, I mean you have a remarkable optimism but I want you to play into the downside so that we can -- you see something that's a little bit better, but that hill is huge.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, I couldn't agree with you more. It is a huge hill to climb. But first of all, just go back to your first comment, Paul's retirement was sudden. It wasn't expected, but you've got to give Paul credit. He's the guy that shepherded this engine throug
componenttext: Howard, I couldn't agree with you more. It is a huge hill to climb. But first of all, just go back to your first comment, Paul's retirement was sudden. It wasn't expected, but you've got to give Paul credit. He's the guy that shepherded this engine through the design, through the development, through the certification. And working nonstop for the last 6 years, you understand why Paul wanted to take a pause. We're very fortunate to have Bob Leduc on the bench with the sale of Sikorsky to hit the ground running over there, and Bob knows the business. He was at Pratt for more than 30 years. He's with UTC for more than 35 years. He knows what needs to be done from a ramp perspective on the operations side, and the team is focused on it. I think again this slow entry into service that we've laid out with Airbus gives us a chance to make sure the supply chain is in sync with our manufacturing facilities. I'll tell you, Howard, with all of the money that we have spent on the capital and infrastructure within UTC operations, I'm confident that we can hit this run rate going forward. These engines don't take long to assemble. It's a question of just making sure all of the parts are there on time, and that's what the focus is going to be at Pratt as well as driving the cost down. So just because Bob's coming in, there is no change to Pratt's guidance, let me be clear on that. There's no change to the ramp schedule. '17 is, I would remind you, 12 months away. I'm not going to give guidance on '17, but we remain confident along with Airbus that we'll be able to meet their requirements going out over the next couple of years.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Akhil actually. Akhil, I wondered if you could give us a little bit more granularity on Q1 at the segment level. It sounded like you were highlighting a -- more of a revenue growth challenge against tough compares in CCS and UTAS. Obviously,
componenttext: Question for Akhil actually. Akhil, I wondered if you could give us a little bit more granularity on Q1 at the segment level. It sounded like you were highlighting a -- more of a revenue growth challenge against tough compares in CCS and UTAS. Obviously, we know about the margin pressure at Pratt. Presumably, those early deliveries have a very negative engine margin not just the sort of averages that you guys talk about. But you also kind of called out negative mix impacts on UTAS on the OEM front. I was just wondering if you could just help us a little bit more at the segment level and understanding those trends and how we work through the year. I know you talked about E&D tailwinds as well, where we see those, primarily at Pratt. Any extra color would be helpful.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think the trends, unfortunately, as you know, at the segment level, '16 is a year where only CCS is talking about a growth in earnings. So the challenge with first quarter is a little more pronounced in the case of UTAS, in the case of Pratt and i
componenttext: Sure. I think the trends, unfortunately, as you know, at the segment level, '16 is a year where only CCS is talking about a growth in earnings. So the challenge with first quarter is a little more pronounced in the case of UTAS, in the case of Pratt and in the case of Otis, where they will recover as the year progresses, but the first quarter is going to be more than disproportionately down in earnings at those segments relative to their full year guidance, right? It's the mix at UTAS that you talked about, Carter. It's the continuing pricing challenge at Otis and the lack of service the company had in Europe. CCS continues to do well, although that has a tough compare in the first quarter based on just a strong organic growth they had 5% organic growth last year.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, 6%.
componenttext: Yes, 6%.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, 6%. I think CCS will have a little bit of challenge. The good news will come, as I said, on the pension side, which will flow through some of this -- all of the segments and the the share count reductions, which is the affective capital deployment th
componenttext: Yes, 6%. I think CCS will have a little bit of challenge. The good news will come, as I said, on the pension side, which will flow through some of this -- all of the segments and the the share count reductions, which is the affective capital deployment that we have been doing. So again, no surprises here, Carter. I don't want to let anybody feel that this is new news. This is something we knew all along when we put the plan and our guidance together. It is just the way the structure of the year is.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: So just trying to get the cadence right. So effectively Q1 will mark a low point for all 4 segments.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, on the GTF, there was a comment in the release today about hitting all its key performance requirements, but could you just update us on the cooling issue, where that stands getting a fix there.
componenttext: Greg, on the GTF, there was a comment in the release today about hitting all its key performance requirements, but could you just update us on the cooling issue, where that stands getting a fix there.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. It's -- we continue to make progress there. I think we've talked about this in detail in December. I would tell you that the Pratt team has identified the fixes as a software fix and a minor hardware fix. Just to be clear, every next-generatio
componenttext: Yes, David. It's -- we continue to make progress there. I think we've talked about this in detail in December. I would tell you that the Pratt team has identified the fixes as a software fix and a minor hardware fix. Just to be clear, every next-generation commercial engine out there has to cool down to a uniform thermal before they start the engine. So this is not something endemic just to the GTF. The starting time of the cooling is a little longer than what customers would've liked. These changes that we're talking about on software and the hardware again, relatively simple to do, not a big cost. And I think importantly, it doesn't change any of the fuel burn or noise or emissions on the engine. These are really pretty minor changes. If you guys are looking for something to worry about, worry about things that we don't control like FX. I wouldn't worry about the technical aspect of GTF. It is rocksolid.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, when would you expect the fix to be in the market?
componenttext: Greg, when would you expect the fix to be in the market?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we expect -- the hardware comes in for the changes in our February build. We'll get those out by -- towards the end of the second quarter. You'll actually see those out there in deliveries. Just given the slower ramp, it's actually beneficial. There's
componenttext: So we expect -- the hardware comes in for the changes in our February build. We'll get those out by -- towards the end of the second quarter. You'll actually see those out there in deliveries. Just given the slower ramp, it's actually beneficial. There's not going to be a lot of engines out there with the old hardware. We will retrofit those over the course of the next year or so. Again, we expect the impact to the customers to be very minimal.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and follow-up, on the aftermarket, pretty good numbers this quarter both at Pratt and UTAS. How are you feeling relative to the forecast you've given for '16? I think pretty much flat to low single-digit growth. Do you think maybe there could be ups
componenttext: Okay, and follow-up, on the aftermarket, pretty good numbers this quarter both at Pratt and UTAS. How are you feeling relative to the forecast you've given for '16? I think pretty much flat to low single-digit growth. Do you think maybe there could be upside? Or how do you feel overall?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're very encouraged by what we saw at the fourth quarter. We've been talking about aftermarket growth. RPMs are up, as I said, 7%. We expect it to be up at least 5% 5.5% this year. Airline profitability remains very, very strong, so we expect the
componenttext: Well, we're very encouraged by what we saw at the fourth quarter. We've been talking about aftermarket growth. RPMs are up, as I said, 7%. We expect it to be up at least 5% 5.5% this year. Airline profitability remains very, very strong, so we expect the guidance that we gave, clearly, we have a very good shot at that. And if there is upside, we'll talk about that at the end of the year as opposed to the beginning of the year.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So big-picture question for you. I think I've been cover you guys almost 15 years and you've been doing restructuring for 15 years. When do we finally see a return on all this restructuring? It's like billions a year, like when does that happen?
componenttext: So big-picture question for you. I think I've been cover you guys almost 15 years and you've been doing restructuring for 15 years. When do we finally see a return on all this restructuring? It's like billions a year, like when does that happen?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ron, we've been doing restructuring -- I've been here and 26 years and I think every year, we've done restructuring amongst those 26 years. The fact is we see that the payoff all the time. As we think about the latest big tranche of restructuring, its
componenttext: So Ron, we've been doing restructuring -- I've been here and 26 years and I think every year, we've done restructuring amongst those 26 years. The fact is we see that the payoff all the time. As we think about the latest big tranche of restructuring, its 2009 to '14, we did about $3 billion of restructuring. You saw a big payoff from that restructuring, in fact almost $3 billion of run rate savings. We'll continue to see savings on this next tranche of restructuring, about $1.5 billion over 4 years from '15 through '18. By 2019, you should see about $900 million of run rate savings. The fact of the matter is, you got to keep doing this. This isn't -- the DNA of UTC is to take cost out to do more with less. It's about productivity every day because the world just gets more competitive. And had we not done the restructuring in the past, we wouldn't be where we are today in terms of product cost and global scale. So I'm -- it's real, it's necessary and it's things that we know how to do.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's also, Ron -- since you're talking big picture, I'll step back on a big picture basis and remind you of the operating margin that UTC had. In mid-'90s when we started doing restructuring, it was 6% and it is 16.7% now, and a lot of that margin expansi
componenttext: It's also, Ron -- since you're talking big picture, I'll step back on a big picture basis and remind you of the operating margin that UTC had. In mid-'90s when we started doing restructuring, it was 6% and it is 16.7% now, and a lot of that margin expansion has been fueled by the continuous restructuring that we do taking cost out. I would also put on SG&A rates against any industrial company and you'll see that our aerospace companies are best-in-class in terms of SG&A as a percent of sales as are our commercial companies. So all that has been fueled. Where we need to continue to work on is reducing our manufacturing footprint as Greg talked about in December, where we have 42 [ph] million square feet that of which 22 are still in high-cost locations and we need to continue to work on that. So productivity is a way of life at UTC. As Greg said, it is part of the DNA and we just need to keep doing that.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just one quick detail. The $900 million to the Canadian government, is that the Bombardier tax? Can you give us more color? What is that?
componenttext: Okay, and then just one quick detail. The $900 million to the Canadian government, is that the Bombardier tax? Can you give us more color? What is that?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, over the last several years, we've had these agreements, multiple agreements with the Canadian government on -- that through which they will provide reimbursement for a portion of our E&D. We had, in turn, promised certain jobs in Canada and cert
componenttext: So look, over the last several years, we've had these agreements, multiple agreements with the Canadian government on -- that through which they will provide reimbursement for a portion of our E&D. We had, in turn, promised certain jobs in Canada and certain supply-chain-related investments. And in return, we had to pay royalties for several years. So where we stood at the end of last year was we had 20-years-plus of variable high royalty payments looking ahead for us, and all we did was crystallize that lability into a certain payment at this point of time, which will pay off in 4 [ph] years. Net-net, it's good news for both the Canadian government and for us. We've essentially given back the E&D funding that they had given to us. We've also taken advantage of a good exchange rate in the process. Canadian dollar is at a pretty decent rate right now, and so I think net-net it's a pretty good thing to do.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Conan company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Conan company.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I joined a little bit late but maybe tell us how many GTFs you delivered in the fourth quarter. And you've mentioned that supplier issues kind of our potential bottleneck. Where are you on that? And are there any other kind of potential kind of restrai
componenttext: So I joined a little bit late but maybe tell us how many GTFs you delivered in the fourth quarter. And you've mentioned that supplier issues kind of our potential bottleneck. Where are you on that? And are there any other kind of potential kind of restraints beyond the cooling issue?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Cai. I think total deliveries on GTF in the fourth quarter were only 5. And keep in mind, that goes to 200 this year. As I think about the technical aspects of the engine, as I said before, this cooling issue, this really proved to be a nonissue. We
componenttext: Yes, Cai. I think total deliveries on GTF in the fourth quarter were only 5. And keep in mind, that goes to 200 this year. As I think about the technical aspects of the engine, as I said before, this cooling issue, this really proved to be a nonissue. We got that issue behind us, I believe. And as far as the rest of the engine goes, so far, it's been rocksolid. It's 15% better on fuel burn. It's 50% better on emissions. It's 75% better on noise when the engine is replacing, and it's been proven in both the development program and the flight test to meet all of those type of criteria. And I think you're going to see airlines winding up to get this. We've got orders for more than 7,000 of these engines, keep in mind. As far as the supply chain, I think it's all of the normal challenges that you have in any ramp-up. Again, we're ramping down the the V2500, ramping up the GTF. There are 500 suppliers on this engine. The fact is there's probably 5 or 10 that cause us concern on a daily basis. Ledoux and the team at Pratt are working all of those issues on a daily basis. We've been putting a lot of resources in the supply chain. So there's no other supplier I would call out here other that to say that we're on top of all of the suppliers and making sure that they meet their commits. Keep in mind that 80% of this engine comes from the supply chain. So supply chain has to be perfectly synchronized with the build plan and that's what we're working to ensure.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Sprague with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Sprague with Vertical Research.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe shifting gears a little bit to the commercial companies. Just couldn't keep up with all the color on CCS. It was unclear to me in the comment of that commercial orders down. Did that include Transicold in that commentary? Could you just speak to the
componenttext: Maybe shifting gears a little bit to the commercial companies. Just couldn't keep up with all the color on CCS. It was unclear to me in the comment of that commercial orders down. Did that include Transicold in that commentary? Could you just speak to the actual commercial HVAC end market and what you're seeing there in the quarter in sales and orders?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure Jeff. So we talked about CCS equipment orders in the quarter being down 5%. That was largely driven by declines in Transicold, which, if you recall last year, we talked about Transicold orders being up more than 50%. So some of that compares, if
componenttext: Yes, sure Jeff. So we talked about CCS equipment orders in the quarter being down 5%. That was largely driven by declines in Transicold, which, if you recall last year, we talked about Transicold orders being up more than 50%. So some of that compares, if you look at sort of across some of the other product lines, global commercial HVAC was down about 2% driven by a softer North America. And both the Fire & Security products business and the Field businesses were down a little bit as well. I guess one bright spot on the Fire & Security sites was that China was actually up in the quarter about 8%, and that was driven by our fire detection alarm business in [indiscernible] down to the GST [ph] business with us all better order rates coming out of their commercial vertical.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the comment about weakness in U.S. export-related, was that also a Transicold comment? Or was it something else.
componenttext: And the comment about weakness in U.S. export-related, was that also a Transicold comment? Or was it something else.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is commercial. It is largely to do with some of the comments in the Middle East, if you will, on the export side where we've seen some weakness.
componenttext: It is commercial. It is largely to do with some of the comments in the Middle East, if you will, on the export side where we've seen some weakness.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just shifting gears, so you started to take a charge by the bullet on repatriation. You see more of that as we move forward? Or are you just kind it's a one-time opportunity you're taking, given the gain on Sikorsky and other dynamics in th
componenttext: And then maybe just shifting gears, so you started to take a charge by the bullet on repatriation. You see more of that as we move forward? Or are you just kind it's a one-time opportunity you're taking, given the gain on Sikorsky and other dynamics in the quarter?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was just -- we were trying to be opportunistic. I think it will bring back about $1.4 billion as a result of that share -- I think the effective tax rate on it is about 17%. So we thought it made sense to do that. Given what we're trying to do thi
componenttext: Yes, it was just -- we were trying to be opportunistic. I think it will bring back about $1.4 billion as a result of that share -- I think the effective tax rate on it is about 17%. So we thought it made sense to do that. Given what we're trying to do this year in terms of another $3 billion of share buyback and $2 billion plus of dividends, it just seemed to be the most advantageous way to get at that cash. There are no further plans to take charges like that. We bring back $500 million to $1 billion a year any way as [indiscernible] we see it, typically at relatively lower tax cost, but this is just kind of a one-time item and probably won't be repeating in the future or the near future at least.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I can just sneak one more in, can you give a little bit more color that the end markets overall seemed to be a little bit better? Do you still think traditional lag effect will kick in at better [indiscernible] on equipment will feed back into serv
componenttext: And if I can just sneak one more in, can you give a little bit more color that the end markets overall seemed to be a little bit better? Do you still think traditional lag effect will kick in at better [indiscernible] on equipment will feed back into service? Or is there some other dynamic there?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're exactly right, Jeff. I think if you look at what makes the service revenue go up, it's essentially conversion of new equipment coming out of warranty into service contracts, and that has been anemic in Europe, as you know. The fact that new eq
componenttext: Yes, you're exactly right, Jeff. I think if you look at what makes the service revenue go up, it's essentially conversion of new equipment coming out of warranty into service contracts, and that has been anemic in Europe, as you know. The fact that new equipment orders are starting to be up, our new equipment sales in EMEA were up in the fourth quarter as well, those will translate into service contracts for the -- down the line. The other aspect is also that the modernization side of the service of business has been hurt significantly as some of these regulations have worked itself out primarily in France, and I think we've hit bottom there. Modernization backlog is actually up, so that should start to turn around as well. So the combination of new equipment sales turning into service contracts and modernization improving should start to turn that, but it is going to be a slow process, as you said, Jeff. It's not going to be -- turn right away.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. Just to put out a couple of data points around that. We talked about Europe, new equipment orders or EMEA new equipment orders being up 20%. They're also up better than 20% for the year including Western Europe, which was also up double digits,
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. Just to put out a couple of data points around that. We talked about Europe, new equipment orders or EMEA new equipment orders being up 20%. They're also up better than 20% for the year including Western Europe, which was also up double digits, so that's encouraging. And then to Akhil's point on the mod side, if you look at the end of 2014, we finished the year with mod backlog down in the teens. It was essentially flat in '15 or flat, but we'd rather see up, but it's certainly a better starting point going into '16 than what we saw last year.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to China on the commercial businesses and the comment that you made that it was a bit of a disconnect between HVAC and Fire & Security orders relative to Otis. Can you just provide a little bit more color on why that disconnect has developed an
componenttext: Going back to China on the commercial businesses and the comment that you made that it was a bit of a disconnect between HVAC and Fire & Security orders relative to Otis. Can you just provide a little bit more color on why that disconnect has developed and what is the way you think that one is the leading indicator over the other? Meaning, does HVAC and Fire & Security begin to follow Otis? Or are we going to begin to see a reversal of Otis and see some better things to come more in line with what we got in HVAC and Fire & Security?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you think about Otis in China, 60%-plus of the Otis business relates to residential construction, and that of course is the market that has been the most hurt [indiscernible] overbuilding and so maybe some of the overleverage that we've seen in the Chi
componenttext: As you think about Otis in China, 60%-plus of the Otis business relates to residential construction, and that of course is the market that has been the most hurt [indiscernible] overbuilding and so maybe some of the overleverage that we've seen in the Chinese economy in the last 5 or 6 years. So it's not surprising to see with Otis orders down a lot more than the rest of the business. On the commercial industrial side, you see again orders were flattish at our commercial HVAC business. That's really what we see in the overall economy, industrial economy. Not much growth. It's not declining the same with the residential space is. I mean if you look at the fire products, that is really more of a consumer-driven purchase as opposed to the residential construction or even industrial, and that was up 8%. So as China makes this transition from this industrial economy to this consumer economy, we can expect to see more of these trends continue. But urbanization is not done, as I said. You still got a huge population of people living in the cities. We're not giving up on the residential elevator market. We still see growth there. We see a lot more growth I think on the service side. Otis' service business, I think we were servicing 165,000 elevators at the end of the year. That's at about 20%. We expect another 20% kind of growth as we go into '16. So the dynamics are not unexplainable. I think you just need to peel it back away or understand the individual dynamics of the businesses.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nigel Coe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nigel Coe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, [indiscernible] a little [indiscernible]. Just wanted a couple of quick questions here. Going back to $1.5 billion of charges in the quarter, is that all cash? And then on the -- I guess on the R&D reimbursements, does that help future indications fo
componenttext: Yes, [indiscernible] a little [indiscernible]. Just wanted a couple of quick questions here. Going back to $1.5 billion of charges in the quarter, is that all cash? And then on the -- I guess on the R&D reimbursements, does that help future indications for margins? It feels like the royalty payment goes away in the future years.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the second question first, Nigel. The Canadian royalty cleared off would probably be a $30 million benefit in '16, but it will result in about $100 million EBIT benefit 4 or 5 years out when the E&D reimbursement were expected to be there, which
componenttext: Sure. So the second question first, Nigel. The Canadian royalty cleared off would probably be a $30 million benefit in '16, but it will result in about $100 million EBIT benefit 4 or 5 years out when the E&D reimbursement were expected to be there, which are going away now, and the royalty payments go away as well. So definitely, benefit to Pratt 4 or 5 years out of about $100 million or so a year. With regard to overall, the cash charges, a lot of these payments -- the Canadian payment, which is the largest one of the $15 billion charge that you refer to, is cash. In 2016, we would probably have a $500 million cash outflow as a result of these charges that we've taken in Q4 of this year, roughly $250 million or so from Canada and another $250 million or so for this tax-related cash repatriation, if you will, right? So that impact -- the rest of it will follow over the course of the next few years.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. And then just quickly on CCS, and I know this question's been asked a few times, but the downtimes in orders, do you have the backlog number to [indiscernible] how did the backlog look year-over-year?
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. And then just quickly on CCS, and I know this question's been asked a few times, but the downtimes in orders, do you have the backlog number to [indiscernible] how did the backlog look year-over-year?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The backlog -- we can get you the exact number later on, but I do believe the backlog was -- because the full year was up for commercial HVAC and the sales were up slightly most the backlog maybe slightly down is what I'm guessing, but we'll get to the ex
componenttext: The backlog -- we can get you the exact number later on, but I do believe the backlog was -- because the full year was up for commercial HVAC and the sales were up slightly most the backlog maybe slightly down is what I'm guessing, but we'll get to the exact number.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't have a number handy, but I would just remind you that on CCS, it's a relatively quick turn, not relatively, very quick turn. So on the HVAC side, you're going to turn orders in a few weeks up to as high as maybe 3 months. And on the Fire & S
componenttext: Yes, we don't have a number handy, but I would just remind you that on CCS, it's a relatively quick turn, not relatively, very quick turn. So on the HVAC side, you're going to turn orders in a few weeks up to as high as maybe 3 months. And on the Fire & Security side, it's essentially a book and ship business. So I would say backlog is a lot more important on the Otis side than CCS.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Deane Dray with RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Deane Dray with RBC Capital.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could comment on whether you see any changes in how UTC is competitively positioned with this announced JCI Tycho merger in commercial building services. We talked about potential consolidation, so this is a big one here. Does that change
componenttext: I was hoping you could comment on whether you see any changes in how UTC is competitively positioned with this announced JCI Tycho merger in commercial building services. We talked about potential consolidation, so this is a big one here. Does that change the equation for you guys at all?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not very much, Deane. I say I think Tycho as part of our business, if you think about it, it's primarily a field business. It's about 75% field, 25% products we obviously compete against them both the field and the product. We're actually more heavily wei
componenttext: Not very much, Deane. I say I think Tycho as part of our business, if you think about it, it's primarily a field business. It's about 75% field, 25% products we obviously compete against them both the field and the product. We're actually more heavily weighted on the product side than the field side. And as far as JCI goes under building efficiency side, obviously, we compete with them against with Carrier. But again they'll take some cost out, as I think you saw in their press release just similar to what [indiscernible] when we put Fire & Security and Carrier together about 3 years ago. So it's nice to see they're running our playbook there, but I don't really see there's a big competitive impact as a result of that.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a question for Akhil on the asbestos charge. How far out have you reserved the asbestos liability? And have there been any changes, material changes in your insurance coverage?
componenttext: And then just a question for Akhil on the asbestos charge. How far out have you reserved the asbestos liability? And have there been any changes, material changes in your insurance coverage?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said earlier, I think we've looked at the potential from all the knowledge we have today of the pending and future expected claims and adjusted that downward for the insurance agreements that we entered into in Q4. So net of those 2 is what you're se
componenttext: As I said earlier, I think we've looked at the potential from all the knowledge we have today of the pending and future expected claims and adjusted that downward for the insurance agreements that we entered into in Q4. So net of those 2 is what you're seeing here. Hopefully, we won't see any greater charges beyond this, but you never know, right? But at this point, based on the best knowledge we have, Deane, we took that into account.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
