headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the United Technologies Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. On the call today are Greg Hayes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Akhil Johri, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Paul Lundstrom, Vice
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the United Technologies Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. On the call today are Greg Hayes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Akhil Johri, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Paul Lundstrom, Vice President, Investor Relations. This call is being carried live on the Internet and there is a presentation available for download from UTC's website at www.utc.com. Please note, except where otherwise noted, the company will speak to results from continuing operations and excluding restructuring costs and significant other items of the recurring and/or nonoperational in nature often referred to by management as significant other items. The company also reminds listeners that the earnings and cash flow expectations and any other forward-looking statements provided in this call are subject to risks and uncertainties. UTC's SEC filings including its 10-Q and 10-K reports provide details on important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated in the forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions] Please go ahead, Mr. Hayes.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Carrie. Good morning, everyone. So a really solid Q2 and a great start to the year. With these results, we're very, very comfortable with our long-term outlook and we continue to be on track to the 2020 growth targets that we laid out bac
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Carrie. Good morning, everyone. So a really solid Q2 and a great start to the year. With these results, we're very, very comfortable with our long-term outlook and we continue to be on track to the 2020 growth targets that we laid out back in March of this year. As I told you previously, we are focused on execution and delivering on our commitments. The old UTC of underpromise and overdeliver is our goal again. As we're seeing results of that focus reflected in our Q2 performance, Q2 adjusted EPS was $1.82, up almost $15 billion of sales. Through the first half, adjusted earnings per share are up 6% on 2% organic sales growth. We're also, of course, raising the bottom end of our guidance by $0.15 in our expected adjusted EPS of $6.45 to $6.60 and we're also increasing the bottom end of our sales expectations. We now see 2016 sales of $57 billion to $58 billion. That's up from our previous expectations of $56 billion to $58 billion, and we continue to expect organic growth of 1% to 3% in what remains a low growth and volatile macroenvironment. 
I'll turn it over to Akhil and Paul in a moment to walk you through the details with 4 key takeaways from today. First of all, execution remains our top priority. The Geared Turbofan's performing exceptionally well in service, 99.8% dispatch reliability with over 5,000 revenue hours of 4 operators. We're meeting our commitments on fuel burn, noise and emissions. Second, we continue to invest and innovate for growth. CCS has introduced several new innovative residential products, and we recently announced Otis partnerships with Microsoft and AT&T to collaborate on digital solutions that will enhance connectivity and the customer experience. Third, we're also, of course, seeing the benefits of our cost reduction efforts and we remain focus on cost reduction -- structural cost-reduction. CCS expanded margins by an exceptional 130 basis points in the quarter and corporate expenses were nearly 20% lower versus last year. Number four, finally, we continue to stay disciplined with our capital and evaluate the best ways to utilize our cash to maximize shareholder value. We'll complete the $6 billion accelerated share repurchase plan in the third quarter, and we're on track to return $22 billion in cash to shareholders from '15 through '17. And we recently announced 2 strategically important acquisitions that are right in the core of our business. Otis will acquire Schindler's service business in Japan and CCS acquired a 70% stake in [indiscernible] which is a heating and cooling business in Europe. This will enhance our offerings to our European customers, just exactly as we said, in the core and disciplined. These are just a few of the many examples on why we're executing our key priorities. Let me turn it over to Akhil and Paul who'll take you through the results and I'll be back in a moment with some closing comments. Akhil?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. Taking a look at Slide 2. Organic sales were up 1% in the quarter. Most recent data on the U.S. economy continues to be encouraging, consumer spending remains strong and job creation, wage growth and unemployment trends point to a steady
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg. Taking a look at Slide 2. Organic sales were up 1% in the quarter. Most recent data on the U.S. economy continues to be encouraging, consumer spending remains strong and job creation, wage growth and unemployment trends point to a steady growth environment, although more likely in the 2% GDP growth range as opposed to the 3%-plus we would all like to see. During the second quarter, our commercial businesses saw 3% growth in the Americas, driven by Otis which was up 10%. Sales at CCS were flat as lower Commercial HVAC exports and Fire & Security sales were offset by 3% growth in U.S. residential HVAC. 
Looking at Europe and the Middle East, sales were flat at both traffic and CCS, reflecting little change in the trends or the macro conditions. While Brexit has caused some uncertainty in the region, we don't expect a near-term impact in our businesses. 
In China, while the number of property transactions and home prices, particularly in the Tier 1 cities, show growth year-to-date, the elevated new equipment market is down and price pressure has increased. For Asia as a whole, sales were down 3%, principally driven by China where, consistent with our expectations, we saw sales at Otis decline 7% while CCS sales in China were down 2%. 
Commercial aerospace sales growth of 7% was primarily driven by another strong aftermarket quarter at Pratt and mid-single-digit growth in both commercial OE and aftermarket in Aerospace Systems. On the military side, sales were down 8% driven by original equipment declines at Pratt primarily due to headwinds from the F-117 program, where, as you know, engine production finished in Q1 this year and declines in the Aerospace Systems aftermarket as the C-5 and the cell [indiscernible] program is now complete. 
Taking a closer look at our end markets on Slide 3. Just a reminder, we'll talk to Otis and CCS orders on a constant currency basis as we usually do. So at Otis, new equipment orders were down 4%, driven by China, where orders were down 14% on a dollar basis. They were up 4% on a unit basis however. Excluding China, new equipment orders at Otis were up 3% with low single-digit growth in the Americas and EMEA in both cases of tough compares. Total equipment orders at CCS were down 4%, driven by transport refrigeration which was down almost 30%. Recall that in Q2 of 2015, Carrier Transicold was up almost 30%. Excluding transport refrigeration, orders were flat in the quarter. Low to mid-single-digit growth in Fire & Security and commercial refrigeration orders was offset by a high single-digit decline in commercial HVAC entirely due to Europe and the Middle East. Commercial HVAC equipment orders in the Americas were up low-single digits with mid-single-digit growth in Asia. While U.S. residential HVAC sales, and that is what we include in the total equipment orders metric, were up 3%, orders were actually up 11% in the quarter. 
Moving to aerospace. At UTC Aerospace Systems, after a slow start in Q1, commercial aftermarket sales were up 5% and Pratt & Whitney saw another quarter of very strong commercial aftermarket sales, up 20% driven primarily by the V2500. 
Moving to Slide 4. Total reported sales of $14.9 billion were up 1% versus the prior year as 1 point of organic growth and 1% from acquisitions were offset by a point of headwind from foreign exchange. Adjusted EPS of $1.82 was up 9%. On a GAAP basis, EPS was $1.71, which included $0.11 of restructuring and other one-time significant items. As Greg said, we continue to focus on cost control and you will see that our restructuring spend year-to-date is about $180 million. Based on the first half spend, we now expect our full year restructuring to be approximately $400 million, down from the $500 million previously discussed. However, we will still realize the expected savings as we have been able to successfully divest a couple of businesses which were on the restructuring list and we have been disciplined about not fully replacing voluntary attrition. 
Free cash flow was 100% of net income in the quarter, driven by strong working capital performance in our commercial businesses, partially offset by the continued Aero ramp related investments at Pratt & Whitney. As Greg said, we have increased the full year outlook and now expect sales of $57 billion to $58 billion and adjusted EPS range of $6.45 to $6.60. With a solid first half, we are confident in raising the low end of the EPS range by $0.15 and we still have about $75 million of contingency at the higher midpoint of $6.53. We continue to expect organic sales growth of 1% to 3% and full year free cash flow to net income in the range of 90% to 100%. 
There are some puts and takes within the business unit guidance that Paul will go through. But as we look to the remainder of the year, we expect the businesses to generate slightly higher earnings in the second half as compared to the first half. We will also benefit from slightly lower share count in the second half. However, this will be entirely offset by higher interest expense in the second half compared to the first half as well as some higher second half expenses below the segments. As a result, second half earnings per share are likely to be around the same level as the first half earnings per share. Bottom line is that we feel very good about our improved outlook for the year. Looking beyond 2016, we continue to see macroeconomic uncertainty and pressures. Two watch items that have recently come on the radar screen after Brexit: one, general strengthening of the U.S. dollar; and second, lower yields on both long and short bonds. As you know, lower discount rates could have a significant impact on our financial expense for 2017 and beyond. While it is still too early, as a reminder, every 10 basis points change in the discount rate is around a $30 million profit impact. 
With that, let me hand it off to Paul to take you through the segments in more detail.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Akhil. I'm on Page 5. And please note I'll be speaking to the segments in constant currency and adjusted to exclude restructuring charges and other significant items as we usually do. Also note, we've included an Appendix on Page 11 with add
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Akhil. I'm on Page 5. And please note I'll be speaking to the segments in constant currency and adjusted to exclude restructuring charges and other significant items as we usually do. Also note, we've included an Appendix on Page 11 with additional segment data that you can use as a reference. Hopefully, that's helpful. 
In the quarter, Otis sales were $3.1 billion. That was up 2% at constant currency. Otis profit at nearly $600 million was down 4%. Continued pricing pressure in China and EMEA, coupled with additional E&D investments, more than offset contribution from higher volume. Foreign exchange translation was a 2-point headwind to sales and a 1-point headwind to earnings. New equipment sales increased 2% led by 24% growth in North America. The North America new equipment business continues to benefit from the strong orders intake we've seen over the last few years, particularly in office space and in hospitality. China new equipment sales were in line with expectations, down 9% in the quarter. Otis service sales were up 3%, driven by high-single digit growth in modernization and repair while maintenance sales were up slightly in the quarter. Better-than-expected foreign exchange translation -- based on better-than-expected foreign exchange translation, we now expect full year operating profit at Otis to be down between $150 million and $200 million, that's a $50 million improvement from the guidance that we laid out in December on low single-digit organic sales growth. 
On the next page, Climate, Controls & Security sales were up 1% at constant currency, with 2 points of growth from acquisitions, the majority of which came from the acquisition of Riello. That growth was -- that growth from acquisitions was partially offset by a 1% organic sales decline. Profits were up 8% at constant currency. FX translation was a 1-point headwind for both sales and profits. 
As with Otis, you can find global segment data in the appendix, but to call out a few highlights. During the quarter, we saw 3% organic sales growth in North America residential HVAC. As you heard us discuss midway through the second quarter, we had a slow start to the cooling season but sales picked up significantly in June. In fact, for residential, it was the best June we've seen in about 7 years. On the other hand, following the weak orders we saw in Q1, Transicold sales were down 6% in the quarter. Weak freight rates in the global shipping lines continue to put pressure on the container business which was down 39%. 
Despite a softer top line, CCS continued to deliver profit growth. Earnings were up 8% driven by benefits from lower commodity costs, restructuring savings and other productivity initiatives. Although operating margins grew to a record 20.4%, we continued to invest in product development, holding E&D to prior year levels. For the year, although first half organic growth was weaker than expected, with easier back half compares, continued productivity momentum and favorable foreign exchange translation, we continue to expect operating profit growth of $100 million to $150 million at actual FX on low single-digit organic sales at Climate, Controls & Security. 
Turning to Aerospace on Slide 7. Pratt & Whitney sales of $3.8 billion were up 4% organically. This was driven by another strong commercial aftermarket quarter, up 20% including 3 points of benefit from a sale of legacy hardware. Strong V2500 activity drove the growth in the form of both pre-buy from the service bulletin and also from where we are in the cycle for this engine. The average age of the V2500 fleet is now about 9 years old, and that's a sweet spot for overhaul activity and we continue to see RPM growth. 
In the large commercial engine business, Geared Turbofan shipments in the quarter were higher than Q1 but less than we expected back in March. Although it's safe to say that our customers would love to take additional engines this year, we continue to expect to deliver about 200 GTF engines in 2016. 
For Pratt Canada, engine shipments were down versus the prior year as we continue to see weaker demand in the general aviation and helicopter markets. Pratt operating profit was $452 million, down 8%. Drop-through from the strong aftermarket volume and benefits from pension and FX were more than offset by headwinds from higher negative engine margin, adverse military mix and higher E&D. 
We also made some additional investments to support the industrial ramp. The absence of last year's gain from the product line sale and contract closeouts or headwind but were offset by favorable contract settlements and the legacy hardware sale I mentioned earlier. For the full year, we now expect the commercial aftermarket to be up mid-single digit. Drop-through from that higher aftermarket volume will be more than offset, however, by headwinds from lower-than-expected military sales, fewer Pratt Canada engine shipments, higher E&D and the additional ramp-related investments. Add it all up, and we now expect operating profit for the year to be down $50 million to $100 million at Pratt & Whitney. 
At Aerospace Systems, operating profit increased 2% -- on 2% organic sales growth in the quarter. Sales growth was led by commercial OE, up 5% with growth on our next-generation platforms, partially offset by declines in legacy. Commercial aftermarket volumes accelerated as anticipated, also up 5% and included growth in parts provisioning and repair. Consistent with our full year outlook, the growth we saw in commercial OE and aftermarket was partially offset by a mid-single-digit decline in military. Military OE sales declines were driven by continued lower legacy fighter trainer and transport programs, while the military aftermarket decline was driven largely by the expected completion of the C-5 [indiscernible] retrofit program. Operating profit growth was driven by strong conversion on higher commercial aftermarket sales, pension tailwind and continued cost reduction progress. As expected, headwinds included adverse military OE mix, primarily from declines in legacy program rates and lower military volume. With first half results largely in line with our expectations, an improving organic growth profile and solid execution on cost reduction initiatives, we continue to expect full year operating profit to be flat to down $50 million on low single-digit sales growth at UTC Aerospace Systems. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Greg.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Paul. So encouraging start to the year with 2% organic growth and slightly better-than-expected earnings. Based on this first half, we feel very good about the year. We obviously raised the low end of the guidance by $0.15. We took up the re
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Paul. So encouraging start to the year with 2% organic growth and slightly better-than-expected earnings. Based on this first half, we feel very good about the year. We obviously raised the low end of the guidance by $0.15. We took up the revenue -- well under the revenue guidance. So we've been very comfortable about the year. But as Akhil noted, let's not get ahead of ourselves. There's still a lot of uncertainty and volatility in the global macro environment and this is a long journey, and we've laid out a plan through 2020. We feel very confident about that plan. For the meantime, we're going to remain focused on our key priorities. That's cost reduction, always doing more with less, investing in innovation for growth, will be disciplined in our capital allocation, and most importantly, we're going to focus on executing on the record Aero backlog. As I said many times before, I've never been more confident in UTC's long-term outlook. With the Aero backlog and the investments we've made in all of our business, we continue to be set up for above GDP growth well into the future. 
With that, let's go ahead and open up the call for questions. Carrie?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Sure. If you notice, Ron, the commercial OE shipments were lower than last year. Also, on the military OE side, we had fewer engine shipments. And then Pratt Canada, OE shipments were lower as well. So I think it is more about the OE story where commercial was -- commercial and military OE was down.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question would be on Otis. So Otis China, you seem to see the price mix delta get quite a bit worse in Q2 than Q1 similar to the market leader there. I think price mix must have been down sort of high teens against down 9 in Q1. So I guess the price mi
componenttext: My question would be on Otis. So Otis China, you seem to see the price mix delta get quite a bit worse in Q2 than Q1 similar to the market leader there. I think price mix must have been down sort of high teens against down 9 in Q1. So I guess the price mix headwind for the year and EBIT is probably bigger than what you guided back in December and March. What are the sort of offsets in the organic earnings guide in Otis? Is it cost-cutting or Europe aftermarket?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Julian, first of all, even though the delta between the value at 14% down versus units up 4% feels large, 18 points, only half of that is pricing. Rest had to do with more the mix, if you will, right? We had last year's significant major projects at
componenttext: Yes, Julian, first of all, even though the delta between the value at 14% down versus units up 4% feels large, 18 points, only half of that is pricing. Rest had to do with more the mix, if you will, right? We had last year's significant major projects at higher value per unit, and this year, that's not been the case. So it's about 9% price out of that delta which is a couple of points worse than what we saw in first quarter, not the dramatic number that you would conclude without having this context. And so it's not really -- I mean, overall, we think pricing per China is just slightly worse for the P&L. In fact, for this year, yes, the margin in backlog is a little worse than what we were expecting. But offset to that, as always in China is to greater cost reduction from suppliers. Price pressure in China is not new. Otis is very used to dealing with that. They also can get significant cost reductions from suppliers and that's what they will do.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the aerospace OEMs. And we saw a supplier yesterday talk about slow payments. I know that they've been pushing change in terms, and just if you can talk a little bit about that. Just I notice the receiv
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the aerospace OEMs. And we saw a supplier yesterday talk about slow payments. I know that they've been pushing change in terms, and just if you can talk a little bit about that. Just I notice the receivables were up about $600 million sequentially, not sure if that plays into it at all, but just what's happening from the OEM customers.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sam, it's Greg. I would say the pressure on cost continues unabated at the OEM levels. We have scope program currently at Airbus. We've talked to Boeing about program for success 2.0. There's obviously a lot of pressure in a very competitive environm
componenttext: Yes, Sam, it's Greg. I would say the pressure on cost continues unabated at the OEM levels. We have scope program currently at Airbus. We've talked to Boeing about program for success 2.0. There's obviously a lot of pressure in a very competitive environment to reduce costs, and we obviously are working with the customers to find ways to take costs out of the product, but it's got to be win-win for us. As far as the payment terms, I know there's been some talk out there. We have not seen any extension of payment terms beyond that which we have in the contract. And we have general terms agreements with both Boeing and Airbus and they paid to those terms. And so we haven't really seen any big deterioration in receivables as it relates to any or either of the operators.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify, Sam. The increase in the receivable you referred to, some of it has to do with the acquisition that we had. And also, we had a very strong June as Paul referred to in the script. So when you have late sales in the quarter, you tend to
componenttext: And just to clarify, Sam. The increase in the receivable you referred to, some of it has to do with the acquisition that we had. And also, we had a very strong June as Paul referred to in the script. So when you have late sales in the quarter, you tend to have more receivables because you just haven't had enough time to collect it as part of your normal terms.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, strong residential HVAC sales in June.
componenttext: Yes, strong residential HVAC sales in June.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Sprague from vertical research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Sprague from vertical research.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to ask, I guess, a multifaceted question on cash. Thank you for the pension color on the P&L. But just thinking about cash this year and into next year, can you give us an update on what, if any, cash call the pension could have next year? An
componenttext: I was hoping to ask, I guess, a multifaceted question on cash. Thank you for the pension color on the P&L. But just thinking about cash this year and into next year, can you give us an update on what, if any, cash call the pension could have next year? And then, Akhil, it was interesting the restructuring is coming down a bit. Is there some cash use relief there? And then finally, the cash working capital actually looked okay in the quarter relative to what I was expecting. How does that play out over the rest of the year and maybe the ability to get in the way some of the safety stock through the next year?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question, Jeff, good to see the focus on cash. But clearly, I think on pensions side, we have no mandatory requirements to fund. Of course, depending on where the discount rate ends up on December 31, the pension deficit could be a little worse than
componenttext: Great question, Jeff, good to see the focus on cash. But clearly, I think on pensions side, we have no mandatory requirements to fund. Of course, depending on where the discount rate ends up on December 31, the pension deficit could be a little worse than what we reported at the end of December last year. But definitely, there is no mandatory requirement for us to fund the domestic pension plan. But we will evaluate it as part of a normal cash utilization capital deployment plans and see if we need to do anything on a voluntary business but no call on it. The second question was about restructuring. It's not a meaningful change, Jeff. The $100 million reduction that I talked about for the year, essentially, with keeping the savings impact could benefit a little bit on the cash side. But again, that's small and it doesn't pay out in 1 year. It generally pays out over a couple of years. And finally, on the working capital, as you know, I think as Greg has mentioned many times, we are not satisfied with where our working capital is, but we also understand the need to make up for some of the weaknesses we still have on our supply chain side to buffer stock, and that is not necessarily going to come down that quickly. It's probably a multi-year effort as we get our suppliers to performing in goal levels, which are very high standards, by the way, and I want people to have 95% or more on-time delivery and less than 500 ppm on quality. All that said, that in order to meet our customer commitments, we will continue to have a little bit of buffer stock for a year or 2 more.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, as you know, it's an expensive game in the commercial engines business. And as I've said before, we're going to invest -- we have invested about $10 billion in CapEx and R&D over the last dozen years or so to bring the products to market. The good
componenttext: Howard, as you know, it's an expensive game in the commercial engines business. And as I've said before, we're going to invest -- we have invested about $10 billion in CapEx and R&D over the last dozen years or so to bring the products to market. The good news is at the end of the year, we should have all of the aircraft engines certified. We get our [indiscernible], we got MRJ, we get Embraer. So big phase of investment is really -- will slow down after this year. We're not done. But in terms of the major spending, we should start to see that turn down. At the same time, you should know, we're going to see an uptick in negative engine margin. And as you look out over the next 10 years or so, you're going to see a big number there and close to another $10 billion of negative engine margin of all of these platforms that's going to step up in the next couple of years to get to about $1 billion in 2018. They will say about at that level. As even though production rates will increase, cost will come down, but that is a significant investment. The good news, of course, is the aftermarket will come. As we saw this quarter on the V, when the engines get out there in that 6-, 7-, 8-year time frame, the engines do need to be overhauled. You will see the returns but this is not a short-term game. These are 30-year programs. The returns remain on track to what we had expected which is well in excess of our cost of capital, but it's not for the faint of heart either. As you know, Howard, we're in for the long term. We've got great engines. The performance has been phenomenal out of the box. Right now, our focus is just on delivering engines and then service them for the next 25 or 30 years.

componenttext: And the just on the transport business, you mentioned the container business was down substantially. What was kind of like core U.S. truck trailer down? And can you just remind us of -- I know that's a profitable business just the margin profile and the mix within there because your margin is really good despite transport being down. So obviously, it wasn't a mix drag that was -- that you weren't able to overcome.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So if you look back a few years ago, the Transicold business, there was some disparity in margins amongst the different segments. Container was quite high and North America truck trailer was quite low, and that's changed over the years. If you
componenttext: Yes, sure. So if you look back a few years ago, the Transicold business, there was some disparity in margins amongst the different segments. Container was quite high and North America truck trailer was quite low, and that's changed over the years. If you look at the average margin that's sort of at the CCS broader average today and there's no major difference between the different segments. A little bit of color just on the quarter, North American truck trailer was essentially flat but orders were down similar to what we saw in the first quarter. Looking ahead to the second half of the year, at least for the North America truck trailer piece, we're largely booked for the third quarter as we should be at this point, so I would say we're okay.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to the military business for a moment, Pratt and UTAS. Greg, you did a nice job of explaining some of the puts and takes there. But I was wondering if you could, perhaps, let us know when you feel like you're going to have the [in
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to the military business for a moment, Pratt and UTAS. Greg, you did a nice job of explaining some of the puts and takes there. But I was wondering if you could, perhaps, let us know when you feel like you're going to have the [indiscernible] comp on a year-over-year basis given the C-17 and the C-5. And then you set the first quarter '17 I guess is the question. And then on Pratt, to you suggest that it was worse than expected this quarter on military. Can you just dive a little bit deeper on why it was worse than expected?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the first question, in terms of when do we expect that turn in the military side, I think on Pratt, probably '16 is most likely a low point because of the mix shift that we have talked about the introduction in the F-117 engines. First quarter next yea
componenttext: So the first question, in terms of when do we expect that turn in the military side, I think on Pratt, probably '16 is most likely a low point because of the mix shift that we have talked about the introduction in the F-117 engines. First quarter next year, you will see improvement there on the F-117 compares. For UTAS, the C-5 that we have talked about, that was -- we saw some benefit of that in the first quarter this year as well. So that 2 compares would become easier starting the second quarter of '17 onwards. For this quarter, slightly weaker than [indiscernible] expectations. Actually a lot of it was in line with what we expected. I didn't necessarily say it was usually weaker than expected because the slight shortfall was on the OE shipment side which was down year-over-year partly due to what our production schedule was and partly due to some parts availability. But I think overall, it was okay.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I echo the comments [indiscernible] very helpful. Unfortunately, [indiscernible] questions, but I'm sure that was the reason, Paul. I mean it sounds like the news flow on the neo engine was posted from Farnborough. Can you maybe just comment on that, Greg
componenttext: I echo the comments [indiscernible] very helpful. Unfortunately, [indiscernible] questions, but I'm sure that was the reason, Paul. I mean it sounds like the news flow on the neo engine was posted from Farnborough. Can you maybe just comment on that, Greg? And just give us an update on the quarterly phasing for the engine shipments in the back half of this year. And on top of that, does that face additional pressure on Pratt margins versus 2Q?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes Nigel, as you saw it coming out of the air show, we had a very productive airshow from an order standpoint, a couple of big orders. Right now, we stand at about 8,200 firm and option orders for the GTF. And I think the operators, as I said, they all s
componenttext: Yes Nigel, as you saw it coming out of the air show, we had a very productive airshow from an order standpoint, a couple of big orders. Right now, we stand at about 8,200 firm and option orders for the GTF. And I think the operators, as I said, they all seem to love the engine. Dispatch reliability is good. So things look very positive from that standpoint. As far as production, I think, it was Akhil or I guess Paul mentioned, we built about 140 engines in the back half of the year. That will probably be spread pretty evenly over both of the next 2 quarters, and that's up from about [ph] 36 engines I think. We built 60 engines, 36 got delivered in the first half. Production ramp is continuing as we expect. A little pressure on negative margin in the back half of the year as we ramp up, but the good news is we're coming down the cost curve exactly as we had expected. We look at it every month. We look at by engine. We're right on that 87% learning curve that Bob Leduc laid out over this year. So we feel good about the cost of the engines. We feel good about the ramp, always a challenge but we're working through it.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wondered if you could expand on that a little bit. It looks like on the commercial OEM revenues, you were sort of off tens of millions, but the off-profit delta year-over-year was probably more like 150 or 200 with Pratt being the vast majority of
componenttext: Greg, I wondered if you could expand on that a little bit. It looks like on the commercial OEM revenues, you were sort of off tens of millions, but the off-profit delta year-over-year was probably more like 150 or 200 with Pratt being the vast majority of that. I wonder if you could speak to the -- are you seeing higher losses per engine? Or is there a nonrecurring cost element? And that just seemed like a pretty large number there on a year-over-year basis.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think the best way to answer that, Carter, would be to give you the EBIT road map, if you will, for Q2 for Pratt, right? So the negative engine margin, first of all, is exactly in line with what we expected. It's not higher than -- there are some add
componenttext: So I think the best way to answer that, Carter, would be to give you the EBIT road map, if you will, for Q2 for Pratt, right? So the negative engine margin, first of all, is exactly in line with what we expected. It's not higher than -- there are some additional ramp-up costs that Paul referred to. But overall, we got about $120 million good news year-over-year on commercial aftermarket. Plus we had another $55 million or so good news between pension and E&D -- I'm sorry pension and FX. Those were offset so $175 million of good news, offset by $70 million of negative engine margin, $50 million on the military mix issue that we have talked about before F-117 principally and others, another $35 million net of pension increase in E&D and then the rest about $50-plus million on Pratt Canada, OE shipment reduction and the ramp-up costs that we talked about. So that's essentially the makeup of the Pratt earnings as to why Pratt earnings were down in spite of good strong commercial aftermarket.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's important, Carter, to point that Pratt is doing what they need to do in terms of investing in the ramp. We've added about 400 people to the supply chain this year to make sure that the suppliers have adequate plans in place to deliver on thei
componenttext: I think it's important, Carter, to point that Pratt is doing what they need to do in terms of investing in the ramp. We've added about 400 people to the supply chain this year to make sure that the suppliers have adequate plans in place to deliver on their commitments for the ramp. And some of that investments that we're making will continue out into next year. It's a little bit more than what we had originally expected, but it's what we need to do to make sure we get these engines out on time. So a little bit higher investments but tracking exactly where we expected on costs.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like what you're saying is you expect now to deliver 175 engines versus 200. How are you doing on the supply chain? Because I know that's been an issue. We are you with all those tactical issues, the start time, the error messages on the engi
componenttext: So it sounds like what you're saying is you expect now to deliver 175 engines versus 200. How are you doing on the supply chain? Because I know that's been an issue. We are you with all those tactical issues, the start time, the error messages on the engines? And when do you expect to have those behind you?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's be clear on the production. We're going to build -- deliver 200 engines this year. We built 60 in the first half of the year. We're going to build about 140 in the back half of the year, which is exactly what we talked about or Bob Leduc talk about
componenttext: Let's be clear on the production. We're going to build -- deliver 200 engines this year. We built 60 in the first half of the year. We're going to build about 140 in the back half of the year, which is exactly what we talked about or Bob Leduc talk about back in March. So timing of revenue recognition might be a little bit different. As I said, actually revenue recognized about 36 in the first half. Again, there's engines that are sitting there on the docks that have been in transit. So we feel good about the build plan. We're not going to come off with the 200. As far as the supply chain goes, there are always challenges. But if you think about this, with 8,000 parts and about 800 different subassemblies in this engine, there's a handful of parts that's causing some pain in the supply chain right now, and Bob and the team are all over this and we will get through this. On the technical stuff, I would tell you it's in the rearview mirror, Cai. The start time, when the software drops, they're pretty well addressed, and this is [indiscernible] through behind us. As I said, 99.8% dispatch reliability with the 4 operators, over 5,000 hours of revenue service since its introduction back in January. So the engine's performing exactly as we had expected. And no surprises on cost, no surprises on delivery.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: How come you're only -- you missed, by -- I guess you delivered 36 but you built 60. How come -- given Airbus claims they want to have the engines, how come you were not able to ship more?
componenttext: How come you're only -- you missed, by -- I guess you delivered 36 but you built 60. How come -- given Airbus claims they want to have the engines, how come you were not able to ship more?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: They won't all go to Airbus, Keep in mind, some go to Embraer, some go to Bombardier, some go to MRJ. There's also a large number of spares that we built in the first half of the year to support the in-service fleet. So it's not just production there. Obv
componenttext: They won't all go to Airbus, Keep in mind, some go to Embraer, some go to Bombardier, some go to MRJ. There's also a large number of spares that we built in the first half of the year to support the in-service fleet. So it's not just production there. Obviously Airbus would like their engines sooner, but we're exactly on the production plan we committed to them earlier this year.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, you mentioned a few times through the call your confidence in your 2 2020 revenue growth targets. And I look at the slide from the Investor Day, there's some pretty strong rates in there. It's a lower 4 and a high of 10 depending on the segment and
componenttext: Greg, you mentioned a few times through the call your confidence in your 2 2020 revenue growth targets. And I look at the slide from the Investor Day, there's some pretty strong rates in there. It's a lower 4 and a high of 10 depending on the segment and all kind of blends to 5 to 6. And I guess the numbers you reported today are pretty good, but we're still walking along these low single-digit organic revenue growth levels, not a ton of reason. I don't think you expect 2017 to materially accelerate from '16. Correct me if that's wrong. So you would kind of need '18, '19, '20 to be growing high-single digits organically. Is that realistic? And what makes that happen outside of the macro getting better?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you need to break that down. As you mentioned, with the 4 segments, I would tell you I've got the highest confidence in Pratt and the new test just based on the backlogs and the skylines coming out of Boeing and Airbus. We know the aircraft are go
componenttext: I think you need to break that down. As you mentioned, with the 4 segments, I would tell you I've got the highest confidence in Pratt and the new test just based on the backlogs and the skylines coming out of Boeing and Airbus. We know the aircraft are going to be built. We've got those in backlog. So Pratt should see close to 10% organic growth. Keep in mind, 200 GTF this year, then 400, then 800. They're ramping up almost 1,500 engines. So you will see growth accelerate on the GTF at all those platforms. And while the V goes away, that gets more than replaced through volumes with the neo plus you've got volumes on Embraer, C-Series, MRJ. All of those things give us pretty very high confidence of the organic outlook at Pratt. And similarly, at UTAS where the Aerospace Systems group, they've got line of sight, probably the 5% to 7% organic growth over this time period. The commercial businesses could be more challenging. I think that is the one soft spot. We saw CCS this quarter down 1% organically, Otis only up 2%. But we're making the right investments. We're spending money on E&D on new products. We're spending money on digital and the commercial side to enhance growth. So [indiscernible] a clear pathway. Now again, we assume the world is going to grow at 3% not 2%. And if the world grows at 3% and we can get a little share with these new products, we could be in that 4%, 5% range as we move towards '17 or '18. But clearly, it's more of a challenge on the commercial side. At the same time, keep in mind, urbanization -- when urbanization trends continue, the growth the middle class continues, all those things favor the commercial products. People need air-conditioners and people need elevators. So we're confident in product mix and in the growth outlook.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Noah, one additional initial data point on the UTAS business. I think we've talked about this. The content per aircraft is significantly higher on the new platforms than the platforms that are being replaced. And we've talked about going from 2 million pe
componenttext: Noah, one additional initial data point on the UTAS business. I think we've talked about this. The content per aircraft is significantly higher on the new platforms than the platforms that are being replaced. And we've talked about going from 2 million per ship set to 4 million per ship set. So even though the production of the aircraft does not increase too much, just the change in the introduction of the new platforms is going to increase the UTAS sales, in any case. So I think Aerospace side has got a very high level of confidence. You don't have to go out and compete those every day again for the 2020 skyline. It's more the commercial businesses.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And Akhil, what's now in the 2016 guidance for euro-dollar?
componenttext: That's helpful. And Akhil, what's now in the 2016 guidance for euro-dollar?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So no change? Or I'm sorry, were you -- you were at $1 before, correct?
componenttext: So no change? Or I'm sorry, were you -- you were at $1 before, correct?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And that's part of the reason why we have increased our bottom end and also the Otis guidance, if you will, because euro has been around $1.12 or so for the first 6 months and we are expecting $1.10 for the next 6 months.
componenttext: Right. And that's part of the reason why we have increased our bottom end and also the Otis guidance, if you will, because euro has been around $1.12 or so for the first 6 months and we are expecting $1.10 for the next 6 months.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you said that aftermarket is now mid-single-digit growth at Pratt in the plan, which Pratt gives you north of $150 million of additional EBIT but the segment came down $50 million, so $200 million of higher EBIT in there being absorbed, I guess, b
componenttext: I think you said that aftermarket is now mid-single-digit growth at Pratt in the plan, which Pratt gives you north of $150 million of additional EBIT but the segment came down $50 million, so $200 million of higher EBIT in there being absorbed, I guess, by E&D and ramp cost. Is that how you'd characterize it?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let's do the full year math on Pratt EBIT [ph]. So the commercial aftermarket will get probably $125 million of good news versus what we expected. That will be offset by $50 million more in E&D, $50 million lower from military business and a remaining
componenttext: So let's do the full year math on Pratt EBIT [ph]. So the commercial aftermarket will get probably $125 million of good news versus what we expected. That will be offset by $50 million more in E&D, $50 million lower from military business and a remaining $75 million from the fewer Pratt Canada engine shipments plus the additional ramp cost that we talked about. So 3 high level things offsetting the good news from commercial aftermarket.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's perfect. And then if we think about, Greg, you said -- this is a follow-up since this is the same question, but you said that the certifications of the engines are all done this your E&D. How quickly does that drop over the next couple of y
componenttext: Got it, that's perfect. And then if we think about, Greg, you said -- this is a follow-up since this is the same question, but you said that the certifications of the engines are all done this your E&D. How quickly does that drop over the next couple of years?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the road map has us going down about $250 million over the next 3 years as we look at the R&D. And just because the engine's certified, it doesn't mean all the flight testing is done. So there still is significant cost out there and we're not goin
componenttext: I think the road map has us going down about $250 million over the next 3 years as we look at the R&D. And just because the engine's certified, it doesn't mean all the flight testing is done. So there still is significant cost out there and we're not going to stop investing in the technology. We're not going to go 0. But clearly, you can expect to see probably in that 4%, 5% range as a percentage of sales going forward.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, wanted to touch on Otis new equipment in North America. The orders were up this quarter but I think the smallest kind of increase we've seen in quite a while. Could you just frame the North American new equipment market? And do you think we've kind
componenttext: Greg, wanted to touch on Otis new equipment in North America. The orders were up this quarter but I think the smallest kind of increase we've seen in quite a while. Could you just frame the North American new equipment market? And do you think we've kind of peaked out there in terms of order rates?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear, the U.S. order rate was actually up, I think, about the 6% in the quarter. Canada was down bigger with some big projects that didn't repeat year-over-year. But we still see growth in the backlog at Otis this quarter in North America. So
componenttext: Just to be clear, the U.S. order rate was actually up, I think, about the 6% in the quarter. Canada was down bigger with some big projects that didn't repeat year-over-year. But we still see growth in the backlog at Otis this quarter in North America. So as it peaked, I don't know if it's peaked, is clearly back to where it was in 2007, which is good news. And probably that -- we won't certainly see double-digit growth. We're not expecting double-digit growth over the next year or 2.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the back half, David, you're right. There was some very strong orders in Otis North America last year like the Hudson yards. So in the back half, we saw almost 50% growth in North American orders last year, and that clearly is going to be tough compare
componenttext: In the back half, David, you're right. There was some very strong orders in Otis North America last year like the Hudson yards. So in the back half, we saw almost 50% growth in North American orders last year, and that clearly is going to be tough compares to jump off of. So don't be surprised if the orders in North America are down year-over-year in the back half. Again, very robust economy. Things still look pretty good. The good news is that the orders, from what we have seen over the last several quarters, are converting into sales now. So the new equipment sales are very strong in North America and we expect that to continue over a period of time.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Harned from Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Harned from Bernstein.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Otis and CC&S, after a few years of cost focus, you've talked about the need to spend more on product development in each of those business areas. Could you give us a sense of where that spending is going to occur? And is this something we should see o
componenttext: On Otis and CC&S, after a few years of cost focus, you've talked about the need to spend more on product development in each of those business areas. Could you give us a sense of where that spending is going to occur? And is this something we should see over the next couple of years and then see a margin benefit subsequently? Could you give us a sense of what that trajectory would be for the 2 businesses?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So we talked about Otis, we're spending only about 1% of sales on E&D. And a very small part of that was on actual new product. Most of the E&D historically has been on cost reduction. We can see that doubling over the next couple of years. We saw
componenttext: Right. So we talked about Otis, we're spending only about 1% of sales on E&D. And a very small part of that was on actual new product. Most of the E&D historically has been on cost reduction. We can see that doubling over the next couple of years. We saw E&D up this quarter at Otis. We'll continue to see it grow over the next couple of years. They're investing in a couple of different things. First of all, refreshing the aesthetics in the cab, very important. We're doing that across the globe, and that's done in each individual market. We're also investing in high-rise, newbuild technology and looking at ways to again enhance the offering on the service side. So investments in new equipment, investments in service technology, investments in service productivity tools. On CCS, they've already doubled E&D over the last 4 years or 5 years. It's been right about 2% of sales, and we should continue at that level. The focus there is really on the large commercial chillers where we have not had a competitive offering for a number of years. Reinvesting in that business, we continue to see big opportunities in the big chiller side, but it won't take several years and some additional R&D expenditures to get the product lines where we needed to be.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are these levels that you expect to continue as sort of a natural level for investment in these businesses? Or would there be a margin benefit that we would expect in a couple of years down the road?
componenttext: Are these levels that you expect to continue as sort of a natural level for investment in these businesses? Or would there be a margin benefit that we would expect in a couple of years down the road?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think Doug you've got to continue at this kind of 2% level of sales. Think about $30 billion commercial business. 2% of sales is about $600 million a year. It's not an unreasonable amount of money, and I want to -- these are long-term businesses. Y
componenttext: Yes, I think Doug you've got to continue at this kind of 2% level of sales. Think about $30 billion commercial business. 2% of sales is about $600 million a year. It's not an unreasonable amount of money, and I want to -- these are long-term businesses. You have to continue to invest. So we're not looking for margin opportunities on the commercial businesses. It's going to come from improving productivity on the service side at Otis and it's going to come from cost reduction on the CCS side.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And are next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.
componenttext: And are next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: R&D was up $30 million year-over-year, Greg, and you've talk about it being up at Pratt, Otis. Can you break out how much it was up in each of the sectors?
componenttext: R&D was up $30 million year-over-year, Greg, and you've talk about it being up at Pratt, Otis. Can you break out how much it was up in each of the sectors?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I mean the number I quoted on Pratt, up $35 million, was excluding pension because that we took out in the math on the good side. So the numbers that you see in the $30 million include the benefit of pension. So the Pratt number was a little nort
componenttext: Sure. So I mean the number I quoted on Pratt, up $35 million, was excluding pension because that we took out in the math on the good side. So the numbers that you see in the $30 million include the benefit of pension. So the Pratt number was a little north of $20 million, about $25 million increase. Otis was another $10 million or $11 million increase and then offset by slight decrease in UTAS, and CCS was slight and corporate office was down slightly. So that's the math, up [ph] 30 [ph].

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then quickly, it looked like F-35 engine deliveries were less than the first quarter where I would've thought they'd be ramping. So can you just talk about what's going on there?
componenttext: Okay. And then quickly, it looked like F-35 engine deliveries were less than the first quarter where I would've thought they'd be ramping. So can you just talk about what's going on there?

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some of it, George, was just simply the Q4 deliveries which got pushed into January. It drove up the Q1 more than what the original schedule was. So I think it was a little bit of a catch-up in Q1 that you saw. Q2 was more in line with what we expected, a
componenttext: Some of it, George, was just simply the Q4 deliveries which got pushed into January. It drove up the Q1 more than what the original schedule was. So I think it was a little bit of a catch-up in Q1 that you saw. Q2 was more in line with what we expected, and I think you will see some ramp-up happening in the second half. But again, the profile was not very different. It was just that Q1 was higher than originally we had expected because of just the move from Q4 to Q1.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that concludes our question-and-answer session for today. I would like to turn the conference back over to Greg Hayes for any closing comments.
componenttext: And that concludes our question-and-answer session for today. I would like to turn the conference back over to Greg Hayes for any closing comments.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Carrie. Thanks all for listening today. As always, the Investor Relations team will be available for follow-up after the call. And thanks very much, and have a wonderful day. Take care.

headline: United Technologies Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
